We feel ourÅ¿elves hurt moÅ¿t by a partial, cenÅ¿orious paragraph, in Mr. Carey's Å¿econd edition, of his account of the Å¿ickneÅ¿s, &c. in Philadelphia; pages 76 and 77, where he aÅ¿perÅ¿es the blacks alone, for having taken the advantage of the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Å¿ituation of the people. Had Mr. Carey been Å¿olicited to Å¿uch an undertaking, for hire, Query, "what would he have demanded? but Mr. Carey, although choÅ¿en a member of that band of worthies who have Å¿o eminently diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed themÅ¿elves by their labours, for the relief of the Å¿ick and helpleÅ¿sâyet, quickly after his election, left them to Å¿truggle with their arduous and hazardous taÅ¿k, by leaving the city. The great prices paid did not eÅ¿cape the obÅ¿ervation of that worthy and vigilant magiÅ¿trate, Mathew ClarkÅ¿on, mayor of the city, and preÅ¿ident of the committeeâhe Å¿ent for us, and requeÅ¿ted we would uÅ¿e our influence, to leÅ¿Å¿en the wages of the nurÅ¿es, but on informing him the cauÅ¿e, i. e. that of the people overbidding one another, it was concluded unneceÅ¿Å¿ary to attempt any thing on that head; therefore it was left to the people concerned. div.head: An AddreÅ¿s to thoÅ¿e who keep Slaves, and approve the practice.
div.p:
THE judicious part of mankind will think it unreaÅ¿onable, that a Å¿uperior good conduct is looked for, from our race, by thoÅ¿e who Å¿tigmatize us as men, whoÅ¿e baÅ¿eneÅ¿s is incurable, and may therefore be held in a Å¿tate of Å¿ervitude, that a merciful man would not doom a beaÅ¿t to; yet you try what you can to prevent our riÅ¿ing from the Å¿tate of barbariÅ¿m, you repreÅ¿ent us to be in, but we can tell you, from a degree of experience, that a black man, although reduced to the moÅ¿t abject Å¿tate human nature is capable of, Å¿hort of real madneÅ¿s, can think, reflect, and feel injuries, although it may not be with the Å¿ame degree of keen reÅ¿entment and revenge, that you who have been and

We believe if you would try the experiment of taking a few black children, and cultivate their minds with the Å¿ame care, and let them have the Å¿ame proÅ¿pect in view, as to living in the world, as you would wiÅ¿h for your own children, you would find upon the trial, they were not inferior in mental endowments.

We do not wiÅ¿h to make you angry, but excite your attention to conÅ¿ider, how hateful Å¿lavery is in the Å¿ight of that God, who hath deÅ¿troyed kings and princes, for their oppreÅ¿Å¿ion of the poor Å¿laves; Pharaoh and his princes with the poÅ¿terity of king Saul, were deÅ¿troyed by the protector and avenger of Å¿laves. Men muÅ¿t be wilfully blind and extremely partial, that cannot Å¿ee the contrary effects of liberty and Å¿lavery upon the mind of man; we freely confeÅ¿s the vile habits often acquired in a Å¿tate of Å¿ervitude, are not eaÅ¿ily thown off; the example of the IÅ¿raelites Å¿hews, who with all that MoÅ¿es could do to reclaim them from it, Å¿till continued in their former habits more or leÅ¿s; and why will you look for better from us? Why will you look for grapes from thorns, or figs from thiÅ¿tles? It is in our poÅ¿terity enjoying the Å¿ame privileges with your own, that you ought to look for better things.

When you are pleaded with, do not you reply as Pharaoh did, "wherefore do ye MoÅ¿es and Aaron, let the people from their work, behold the people of the land, now are many, and you make them reÅ¿t from their burdens." That God who knows the hearts of all men, and the propenÅ¿ity of a Å¿lave to hate his oppreÅ¿Å¿or, hath Å¿trictly forbidden it to his choÅ¿en people, "thou Å¿halt not
abhor an Egyptian, becauÅ¿e thou waÅ¿t a Å¿tranger in his land. Deut. xxiii. 7." We feel the obligations, we wiÅ¿h to impreÅ¿s them on the minds of our black brethren, and that we may all forgive you, as we wiÅ¿h to be forgiven; we think it a great mercy to have all anger and bitterneÅ¿s removed from our minds; we appeal to your own feelings, if it is not very diÅ¿quieting to feel yourÅ¿elves under the dominion of a wrathful diÅ¿poÅ¿ition.

If you love your children, if you love your country, if you love the God of love, clear your hands from Å¿laves, burden not your children or country with them. Our hearts have been Å¿orrowful for the late bloodÅ¿hed of the oppreÅ¿Å¿ors, as well as the oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, both appear guilty of each others blood, in the Å¿ight of him who Å¿aid, he that Å¿heddeth man's blood, by man Å¿hall his blood be Å¿hed.

Will you, becauÅ¿e you have reduced us to the unhappy condition our colour is in, plead our incapacity for freedom, and our contented condition under oppreÅ¿Å¿ion, as a Å¿ufficient cauÅ¿e for keeping us under the grievous yoke? We have Å¿hewn the cauÅ¿e of our incapacity, we will alÅ¿o Å¿hew, why we appear contented; were we to attempt to plead with our maÅ¿ters, it would be deemed inÅ¿olence, for which cauÅ¿e they appear as contented as they can in your fight, but the dreadful inÅ¿urrections they have made, when opportunity has offered, is enough to convince a reaÅ¿onable man, that great uneaÅ¿ineÅ¿s and not contentment, is the inhabitant of their hearts.

div.head: To the People of Colour.
div.p: FEELING an engagement of mind for your welfare, we addreÅ¿s you with an affectionate Å¿ympathy, having been ourÅ¿elves Å¿laves, and as deÅ¿irous of freedom as any of you; yet the bands of bondage were Å¿o Å¿trong, that no way appeared for our releaÅ¿e, yet at times a hope aroÅ¿e in our hearts that a way would open for it, and when our minds were mercifully viÅ¿ited with the feeling of the love of God, then theÅ¿e hopes increaÅ¿ed, and a confidence aroÅ¿e that he would make way for our enlargement, and as a patient waiting was neceÅ¿Å¿ary, we were Å¿ometimes favoured with it, at other times we were very impatient, then the proÅ¿pect of liberty almoÅ¿t vaniÅ¿hed away, and we were in darkneÅ¿s and perplexity.

We mention our experience to you, that your hearts may not Å¿ink at the diÅ¿couraging proÅ¿pects you may have, and that you may put your truÅ¿t in God, who Å¿ees your condition, and as a merciful father pitieth his children, Å¿o doth God pity them that love him; and as your hearts are inclined to Å¿erve God, you will feel an affectionate regard towards your maÅ¿ters and miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es, and the whole family where you live, this will be Å¿een by them, and tend to promote your liberty, eÅ¿pecially with Å¿uch as have feeling maÅ¿ters, and if they are otherwiÅ¿e you will have the favour and love of God dwelling in your hearts, which you will value more than any thing elÅ¿e, which will be a conÅ¿olation in the worÅ¿t condition you can be in, and no maÅ¿ter can deprive you of it; and as life is Å¿hort and uncertain, and the chief end of our having a being in this world, is to be prepared for a better, we wiÅ¿h you to think of this more than any thing elÅ¿e: then will you have a view of that freedom which the Å¿ons of God enjoy; and if the troubles of your condition end with your lives, you will be admitted to the freedom which God hath prepared for thoÅ¿e of all colours that love him; here the
power of the moÅ¿t cruel maÅ¿ter ends, and all Å¿orrow and tears are wiped away.

To you who are favoured with freedom; let your conduct manifeÅ¿t your gratitude toward the compaÅ¿Å¿ionate maÅ¿ters who have Å¿et you free, and let no rancour or ill-will lodge in your breaÅ¿ts for any bad treatment you may have received from any; if you do, you tranÅ¿greÅ¿s againÅ¿t God, who will not hold you guiltleÅ¿s, he would not Å¿uffer it even in his beloved people IÅ¿rael, and can you think he will allow it unto us?

There is much gratitude due from our colour towards the white people, very many of them are inÅ¿truments in the hand of God for our good, even Å¿uch as have held us in captivity, are now pleading our cauÅ¿e with earneÅ¿tneÅ¿s and zeal; and we are Å¿orry to Å¿ay, that too many think more of the evil, than of the good they have received, and inÅ¿tead of taking the advice of their friends, turn from it with indifference; much depends upon us for the help of our colour more than many are aware; if we are lazy and idle, the enemies of freedom plead it as a cauÅ¿e why we ought not to be free, and Å¿ay we are better in a Å¿tate of Å¿ervitude, and that giving us our liberty would be an injury to us, and by Å¿uch conduct we Å¿terngthen the bands of oppreÅ¿Å¿ion, and keep many in bondage who are more worthy than ourÅ¿elves; we intreat you to conÅ¿ider the obligations we lay under, to help forward the cauÅ¿e of freedom, we who know how bitter the cup is of which the Å¿lave hath to drink, O how ought we to feel for thoÅ¿e who yet remain in bondage? Will even our friends excuÅ¿e, will God pardon us, for the part we act in making Å¿trong the hands of the enemies of our colour.

WE feel an inexpreÅ¿Å¿ible gratitude towards you, who have engaged in the cauÅ¿e of the African race; you have wrought a deliverance for many, from more than Egyptian bondage, your labours are unremitted for their complete redemption, from the cruel Å¿ubjection they are in.
